unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Making Decisions from Output | 2 of 2
question_text:
A veterinarian decided to study the weights (kg) of Siberian and Alaskan huskies.
The veterinarian weighted $13$ randomly selected Siberian Huskies and $12$ randomly selected Alaskan Huskies. A two-sample $t$-test was performed with the results below (two-sided).
Two-Sample $t$ for Siberian Husky vs. Alaskan Husky:
$\text{Difference }= \mu \text{(Siberian husky)}-\mu \text{(Alaskan husky)}$
Estimate for difference: $-4.61$
$95\%$ confidence interval for difference: $(-7.3, -1.91)$
$\text{T-test of Difference }= 0$ $\text{T-value }= -3.56$ $\text{P-value }= 0.002$ $\text{DF }= 20$
What are the appropriate test statistic and $p$-value for this problem?
solution:
The test statistic, $T$, represents how many standard deviations away from the mean the difference is. In this situation, $T = -3.56$.

The $p$-value, as stated in the problem, is $0.002$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
